Paper: Modeling the detection of textual cyberbullying.
Definition of Cyber-Bullyning:
cyberbullying can be defined as the following: 'when the
Internet, cell phones or other devices are used to send or
post text or images intended to hurt or embarrass another
person’
Dataset: youtube vidoes on these senstive topics(50,000)
Data Collection process:
2 annotators labelled the comments into 
race, sexuality, intelligence and none
Text Feature:
Tf-idf unigrams,
profanity words,
frequently POS bigrams,
venue: Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence
Comments: Binary classififcation is better than multiclassififcation

Paper: Sentiment analysis for effective detection of cyber bullying
Dataset:
kongregate (4,802)
slashdot (4,303)
myspace (1,946)
twitter (4865) data from CAW 2
Data Collection process: Twitter data is from CAW2 and the rest borrowed from othe researchers
Text Feature: BOW
Innovative model: Graph model to detct bullyies and victims
Comments: I do not trust the results as they used acciracy which might reflect the TN which is overwhelming in the dataset

Paper: Expert knowledge for automatic detection of bullies in social networks
Definition of Cyber-Bullyning:
Cyberbullying is defined as an aggressive, intentional
act carried out by a group or individual, using electronic forms of contact repeatedly
and over time against a victim who cannot easily defend him or herself
Data Collection process:
2 graduate studentns labeled the users as bullies or not 
with inter agreement Kappa of 0.78
Text Feature:
no profane words,
length of comment,
misspellings and short words,
comments targeted to someone
tf-idf
User info features:
hidden identities,
age of user,
period of membership,
no uploads,
no subscrptions,
no comments
Other features:
A) Experts: a panel of 12 experts in the area of cyberbullying was asked to answer questions about the features presented in Table 1. For each feature they indicated 1) the
likelihood that a bully user belongs to a certain category relevant for that feature and
2) the importance of that feature. The likelihood was indicated on four-point scale
‘Unlikely’, ‘Less likely’, ‘Likely’ and ‘Very likely’ corresponding to values 0.125,0.375, 0.625 and 0.875 respectively
B)MCES decision making systems
Comments:
2- We demonstrated that the expert system outperforms the machine
learning models and the hybrid approach results in a further but marginal improvement in prediction performance
1- compare three types of automatic detection: an expert system, supervised machine learning models, and a hybrid type combining the two.

Paper: Aggressive Text Detection for Cyberbullying
Definition of Cyber-Bullyning: the continuous intentional aggression over an indefense victim via electronic media is known as cyberbullying
Text Feature:
document length,
number of offensive words,
frequency of word "you",
swear words
Sentiment features:
1-The overall affective value for a given word (as well as the value for each of
the differentials) lies within the range [1, 9], where 9 is the closest to happiness.
2-SentiWordNet assigns each synset three classifications with respect to confidence
negativity, positivity, and objectivity
Comments: statistical analysis more than feature engineering or model selecion

Paper: Careful what you share in six seconds: Detectingcyberbullying instances in Vine
Definition of Cyber-Bullyning:
considering cyber bullying a sub category in cyber aggression 
Cyberaggression is defined as aggressive online behavior
that uses digital media in a way that
is intended to cause harm to another
person.Cyberbullying is one
form of cyberaggression that is more
restrictively defined as
 1- an act of aggression online with 
2- an imbalance of power between the individuals
involved  
3- repetition of the aggression.
Dataset:
Vine(969 media sessions)
session per a user
Data Collection process:
labelled by experts and amatures 
on CrowdFlower platform. 5 labellers per post. Agreement for aggressive 76.6% and for bullying 79.49%
Text Feature:
ngrmass
no likes
no comments
Sentiment features:
sentiment of comment
sentiment of post caption
venue:
International conference on Advances in 
social media analysis and mining 2015

Paper: Deep Learning for Detecting Cyberbullying Across Multiple Social Media Platforms
Definition of Cyber-Bullyning:
Cyberbullying has been defined by the National Crime Prevention Council as
the use of the Internet, cell phones or other devices to send or post text or images
intended to hurt or embarrass another person.
Dataset positive sample:
Formspring (825 = 6.8%)
Twitter (3117 sexism = 19.4%)
Twitter (1957 racis = 12.2%)
Wikipedia (13,590 = 13.59%)
Data Collection process:
Formspring (AMT - 3 workers no inter-annotator agreement)
Twitter (Labelled by ressearchers)
Wikipedia (crowdflower - 10 workers - 0.45 agreement score)
Oversampleing pst instances: oversample bullying class data by 3 times
Text Feature:
BOW n-gram words 
BOW n-gram characters
Glove
SSWE
Deel Learning model: CNN, LSTM, BLSTM, BLSTM + attention, CNN
Innovative model:
using transfer learning
 to learn between
 different platforms
Comments:
1-We have shown that DNN models can be used for cyberbullying detection on
various topics across multiple SMPs using three datasets and four DNN models.
These models coupled with transfer learning beat state of the art results for
all three datasets.

Paper: Detecting Hate Speech on Twitter Using a Convolution-GRU Based Deep Neural Network
Definition of Cyber-Bullyning:
we identify that hate speech
(1) targets individual or groups on the basis of their characteristics (targeting
characteristics); (2) demonstrates a clear intention to incite harm, or to promote
hatred; (3) may or may not use offensive or profane words.
Data Collection process:
annotated by liguistic researcher and 2 student researchers 
(agreement score not given)
Oversampleing pst instances:
filtering twitter api using keywords
 and hashtags in 3 batches
Sentiment features:
sentiment polarity 
scores of the tweet
Comments:
it sets new benchmark by outperforming on 6 out of 7 datasets by between
1 and 13% in F1. We also extend the existing dataset collection on this
task by creating a new dataset covering different topics.

Paper: Understanding Cyberbullying on Instagram and Ask.fm via Social Role Detection
Data Collection process:
The labeled Instagram
comments are chosen from top 200 media sessions ranked
by the number of insulting words which appeared in the comments
of the media session, the percentage of negative comments, and the
absolute number of negative comments on the med
Text Feature:
73 features from LIWC2015 categories [15], the compound sentiment
score from VADER [10], and 7 basic linguistic features (e.g.,
the number of upper case words)
Comments:
In this work, we focus our analysis on three different social roles
in cyberbullying: victim, bully, and supporter. Figure 2 describes
the pipeline of our social role detection method. Social roles are
identified based on the aggressive label of comments
